data: [{"id":"47de99dc-0bd7-5dd0-b3a6-a5410814a191","relation":"","identifier":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/your-network-inside-the-business","title":"Your network inside the business","paper_abstract":"This article provides advice for managers on how to expand their influence within their organization by building relationships with staff in other departments. By doing so, managers can gain firsthand experience of challenges faced by other teams, participate in strategic discussions, and increase their profile in the company. The article offers tips for getting introduced to the right people, such as asking for recommendations from peers and line managers and introducing oneself via email.","published_in":"The Engineering Manager blog","year":"2017","subject_orig":"Building your influence, network, connections","subject":"Building your influence, network, connections","authors":"Stanier, James","link":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/your-network-inside-the-business","oa_state":"2","url":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/your-network-inside-the-business","relevance":51,"lang_detected":"english","cluster_labels":"networking, connections, influence","x":"0.0336057408338733","y":"0.0336057408338733","area_uri":4,"area":"networking, connections, influence","resulttype":"Blog Article"},{"id":"0a462340-d6e5-53d9-8d72-e3e3c24fd574","relation":"","identifier":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/culture/","title":"Culture","paper_abstract":"This article explores what company culture is and how it is fostered within technology companies. The author highlights the importance of a compelling vision and purpose for the company, which defines the direction and guides decision-making. Culture emerges from interactions within the company and between the company and the outside world, and is fostered by caring and challenging relationships between individuals. The article emphasizes that perks do not make a strong culture, and that a company can still be dysfunctional despite offering nice benefits.","published_in":"The Engineering Manager blog","year":"2017","subject_orig":"Work culture, organizational culture, values","subject":"Work culture, organizational culture, values","authors":"Stanier, James","link":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/culture/","oa_state":"2","url":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/culture/","relevance":118,"lang_detected":"english","cluster_labels":"culture, values","x":"0.0336057408338733","y":"0.0336057408338733","area_uri":1,"area":"culture, values","resulttype":"Blog Article"},{"id":"252762a4-0864-59f1-8e9f-6a7a1b12625a","relation":"","identifier":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/the-trichotomy-of-control/","title":"The Trichotomy of Control","paper_abstract":"This article discusses the Trichotomy of Control - a concept in Stoic philosophy that states that there are three types of things in the world: things that are completely under our control, things that are not under our control, and things that are partially under our control. The author applies this concept to engineering management, arguing that focusing on things outside of our control, such as the behavior of others, can lead to frustration and anxiety. Instead, managers should focus on the things that are within their control, such as their own behavior and actions, and seek to influence the things that are partially under their control. By doing so, managers can reduce stress and be more effective in their roles. The article offers practical tips for applying the Trichotomy of Control to engineering management, such as reframing problems in terms of what is and is not under our control, and focusing on the process rather than the outcome.","published_in":"The Engineering Manager blog","year":"2018","subject_orig":"Engineering management, administration","subject":"Engineering management, administration","authors":"Stanier, James","link":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/the-trichotomy-of-control/","oa_state":"2","url":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/the-trichotomy-of-control/","relevance":118,"lang_detected":"english","cluster_labels":"management","x":"0.0336057408338733","y":"0.0336057408338733","area_uri":2,"area":"management","resulttype":"Blog Article"},{"id":"6bf88e39-2781-5053-a200-f7dbe235f730","relation":"","identifier":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/rockstars-and-superstars/","title":"Rockstars and superstars","paper_abstract":"This blog discusses how engineers can work towards the individual contributor (IC) track or the management track, and how it is important to identify whether high performers are rockstars or superstars. Rockstars are motivated by being consistent, focused experts, while superstars thrive on new opportunities and variety in their work. Superstars may find stagnation frustrating, while rockstars may become frustrated by changes in circumstances. It is important to understand what motivates each type of performer to ensure they are happy and fulfilled in their roles and to place them in projects and teams where they will perform their best.","published_in":"The Engineering Manager blog","year":"2017","subject_orig":"Career progression","subject":"Career progression","authors":"Stanier, James","link":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/rockstars-and-superstars/","oa_state":"2","url":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/rockstars-and-superstars/","relevance":32,"lang_detected":"english","cluster_labels":"career growth","x":"0.0336057408338733","y":"0.0336057408338733","area_uri":3,"area":"career growth","resulttype":"Blog Article"},{"id":"d1e36009-5cb8-504f-8480-b7f202c3f65d","relation":"","identifier":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/rockstars-and-superstars/","title":"Wobble","paper_abstract":"This blog post on The Engineering Manager discusses the challenges of dealing with uncertainty and high emotion in management positions. The author uses the metaphor of a jelly mold to illustrate how organizations can 'wobble' under the weight of unstructured and emotional input, particularly at higher levels of the organization. The post provides guidance for managers on how to prevent this wobble by practicing emotional intelligence, judgment, and support when difficult situations arise. The author emphasizes the importance of mindful listening and observation, digesting information before communicating it to your team, reframing messages to focus on the positive, and building a peer support network.","published_in":"The Engineering Manager blog","year":"2017","subject_orig":"Organizational design, emotional intelligence, judgment","subject":"Organizational design, emotional intelligence, judgment","authors":"Stanier, James","link":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/rockstars-and-superstars/","oa_state":"2","url":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/rockstars-and-superstars/","relevance":72,"lang_detected":"english","cluster_labels":"management","x":"0.0336057408338733","y":"0.0336057408338733","area_uri":2,"area":"management","resulttype":"Blog Article"},{"id":"f4152628-8869-4137-a493-d1e31d58db19","relation":"","identifier":"https://theengineeringmanager.substack.com/p/fast-forwarding-decision-making?utm_source=twitter&sd=pfhttps://theengineeringmanager.substack.com/p/fast-forwarding-decision-making?utm_source=twitter&sd=pf","title":"Fast-forwarding decision making","paper_abstract":"The article discusses how organizations waste time in decision making by engaging in the theatre of decision making, which creates delay rather than progress. The author advises holding oneself accountable for making decisions and progressing discussions as quickly as possible by being creative about ways of shaving minutes, hours, and days from a decision point.","published_in":"The Engineering Manager","year":"2023","subject_orig":"decision making, progress, delay, accountability, creativity","subject":"decision making, progress, delay, accountability, creativity","authors":"James Stanier","link":"https://theengineeringmanager.substack.com/p/fast-forwarding-decision-making?utm_source=twitter&sd=pfhttps://theengineeringmanager.substack.com/p/fast-forwarding-decision-making?utm_source=twitter&sd=pf","oa_state":"2","url":"https://theengineeringmanager.substack.com/p/fast-forwarding-decision-making?utm_source=twitter&sd=pfhttps://theengineeringmanager.substack.com/p/fast-forwarding-decision-making?utm_source=twitter&sd=pf","relevance":100,"lang_detected":"english","x":"0.0336057408338733","y":"0.0336057408338733","cluster_labels":"management","area_uri":2,"area":"management","resulttype":"Blog Article"},{"id":"4f8e7a45-5189-4a6c-a0e2-f4896fe94fd0","relation":"","identifier":"http://theengineeringmanager.com/growth/scrutiny-and-judgement/","title":"Scrutiny and Judgement","paper_abstract":"The scrutiny and judgement faced by public figures is not unique to them. As you progress in your management career, you will find that senior positions invite more scrutiny from your colleagues. The visibility of those in power encourages scrutiny, and during good times, they can be fantastic role models. But during bad times, fingers will be pointed at them, despite the net result of the current situation being generated by the whole organization. Coping strategies for those in positions of power include compartmentalizing their personality into their \"work\" self and their \"home\" self, but it can become exhausting. Judgement can come from both directions, and to deal with it, one must be themselves, warts and all. ","published_in":"The Engineering Manager","year":"2017","subject_orig":"scrutiny, judgement, management, leadership, coping strategies","subject":"scrutiny, judgement, management, leadership, coping strategies","authors":"James Stanier","link":"http://theengineeringmanager.com/growth/scrutiny-and-judgement/","oa_state":"2","url":"http://theengineeringmanager.com/growth/scrutiny-and-judgement/","relevance":100,"lang_detected":"english","x":"0.0336057408338733","y":"0.0336057408338733","cluster_labels":"management","area_uri":2,"area":"management","resulttype":"Blog Article"},{"id":"417c8b5f-51f4-4a0e-a058-5a2a6b174004","relation":"","identifier":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/the-stick/","title":"The Stick","paper_abstract":"The article discusses the use of the \"stick\" approach to motivate teams to work harder or faster. It explores the reasons why teams may be asked to work harder and the reasons why the stick approach may not work for software engineering teams. The article suggests that the stick approach is not effective for teams that are in an industry where demand for talent is high and where employees are self-motivated. ","published_in":"The Engineering Manager","year":"2017","subject_orig":"stick approach, software engineering, motivation, talent, self-motivated","subject":"stick approach, software engineering, motivation, talent, self-motivated","authors":"James Stanier","link":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/the-stick/","oa_state":"2","url":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/the-stick/","relevance":100,"lang_detected":"english","x":"0.0336057408338733","y":"0.0336057408338733","cluster_labels":"management","area_uri":2,"area":"management","resulttype":"Blog Article"},{"id":"08b8083e-9483-4d96-ae29-5c3942a20dc1","relation":"","identifier":"https://sapalo.dev/2020/08/26/prioritization/","title":"Mental Model: Prioritization and Learning","paper_abstract":"The blog post discusses the phases of learning a new skill, using software development as an example. It begins with making things work, then making them correct, followed by making them usable and optimizing them. Finally, aesthetics is considered. ","published_in":"Darren SapaloTech Consulting","year":"2020","subject_orig":"mental model, prioritization, learning, software development, aesthetics, usability, optimization, functionality","subject":"mental model, prioritization, learning, software development, aesthetics, usability, optimization, functionality","authors":"Darren Sapalo","link":"https://sapalo.dev/2020/08/26/prioritization/","oa_state":"2","url":"https://sapalo.dev/2020/08/26/prioritization/","relevance":30,"lang_detected":"english","x":"0.0336057408338733","y":"0.0336057408338733","cluster_labels":"problem solving","area_uri":6,"area":"problem solving","resulttype":"Blog Article"},{"id":"9b3670da-26ae-4baa-a81e-3cfd0c3b37ca","relation":"","identifier":"https://theengineeringmanager.substack.com/p/fast-forwarding-decision-making?utm_source=twitter&sd=pf","title":"Fast-forwarding decision making","paper_abstract":"The article highlights how organizations waste time on decision-making, involving indirect actions that feel like progress but contribute nothing to it. The author suggests holding oneself accountable for making decisions and progressing discussions as quickly as possible, by whatever means necessary, and being creative about ways of shaving minutes, hours, and days from a decision point.","published_in":"The Engineering Manager","year":"2023","subject_orig":"decision-making, progress, accountability, time management, consensus","subject":"decision-making, progress, accountability, time management, consensus","authors":"James Stanier","link":"https://theengineeringmanager.substack.com/p/fast-forwarding-decision-making?utm_source=twitter&sd=pf","oa_state":"2","url":"https://theengineeringmanager.substack.com/p/fast-forwarding-decision-making?utm_source=twitter&sd=pf","relevance":100,"lang_detected":"english","x":"0.0336057408338733","y":"0.0336057408338733","cluster_labels":"management","area_uri":2,"area":"management","resulttype":"Blog Article"},{"id":"462db478-045c-42f2-b811-fd3327bcb7a7","relation":"","identifier":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/coaching/","title":"Coaching for Managers: A Framework for Improving Staff Performance","paper_abstract":"The article discusses the importance of coaching as a tool for improving the performance of staff. Coaching is defined as a framework for interactions with colleagues that can have tangible positive effects on their work. The article presents three main concepts of coaching, including the mode of conversation, keeping the thought bubble over the staff's head, and the GROW model. The article emphasizes that coaching doesn't require special planning or skills and can be used in both formal and informal settings.","published_in":"The Engineering Manager","year":"2017","subject_orig":"coaching, staff performance, management, framework, GROW model","subject":"coaching, staff performance, management, framework, GROW model","authors":"James Stanier","link":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/coaching/","oa_state":"2","url":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/coaching/","relevance":100,"lang_detected":"english","x":"0.0336057408338733","y":"0.0336057408338733","cluster_labels":"management","area_uri":2,"area":"management","resulttype":"Blog Article"},{"id":"522dac90-62c2-41f3-90f4-520341aeddd3","relation":"","identifier":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/mount-stupid/","title":"Mount Stupid","paper_abstract":"The article discusses the psychological concepts of the Dunning-Kruger effect and Impostor syndrome and how they can affect the workplace. The author explains how the Dunning-Kruger effect can lead to poor decisions made by junior engineers and rash decisions made by managerial staff. The article also includes a humorous graph illustrating the most dangerous place in the Dunning-Kruger effect. ","published_in":"The Engineering Manager","year":"2017","subject_orig":"Dunning-Kruger effect, Impostor syndrome, workplace, engineering","subject":"Dunning-Kruger effect, Impostor syndrome, workplace, engineering","authors":"James Stanier","link":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/mount-stupid/","oa_state":"2","url":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/mount-stupid/","relevance":100,"lang_detected":"english","x":"0.0336057408338733","y":"0.0336057408338733","cluster_labels":"management","area_uri":2,"area":"management","resulttype":"Blog Article"},{"id":"f281e494-1c11-44b1-9e13-d4554bc78f59","relation":"","identifier":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/ownership/","title":"Ownership","paper_abstract":"In this blog post, James Stanier discusses the importance of taking total ownership of collective output in software development teams. He highlights the common issue of wasted time between phases of work and how individual focus on productivity can cause total productivity of the group to suffer. Stanier suggests that a Responsibility Assignment Matrix (RACI) can be useful in clarifying roles and responsibilities within a team, but emphasizes that ownership is primarily a change in mindset rather than a change in process. He warns against hiding behind definitions and processes, and encourages individuals to care about everything, as start-ups do.","published_in":"The Engineering Manager","year":"2018","subject_orig":"ownership, productivity, software development, Responsibility Assignment Matrix (RACI), roles and responsibilities, start-ups","subject":"ownership, productivity, software development, Responsibility Assignment Matrix (RACI), roles and responsibilities, start-ups","authors":"James Stanier","link":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/ownership/","oa_state":"2","url":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/ownership/","relevance":100,"lang_detected":"english","x":"0.0336057408338733","y":"0.0336057408338733","cluster_labels":"management","area_uri":2,"area":"management","resulttype":"Blog Article"},{"id":"8b97d9b9-7e5f-425e-a5fb-386e4540be3d","relation":"","identifier":"https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/growth/keeping-your-1-to-1s-fresh/","title":"Keeping Your 1 to 1s Fresh","paper_abstract":"The article discusses the importance of 1 to 1 meetings between managers and employees and how to keep them fresh and engaging.
